articles.headline: Ukraine Launches Rare Missile Strikes in Russia, Moscow Says
articles.snippet: Kyiv did not take responsibility for the attacks, which could be a bid to broaden a war that has mostly rained ruin and death on Ukraine.
articles.abstract: Kyiv did not take responsibility for the attacks, which could be a bid to broaden a war that has mostly rained ruin and death on Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: Moscow said it shot down two Ukrainian missiles over southwestern Russia on Friday, including one that fell and exploded in a city center — apparently rare instances of Ukraine using such powerful weapons to attack targets inside Russia.
articles.byline: By Marc Santora and Anton Troianovski

articles.headline: New Trump Charges Highlight Long-Running Questions About Obstruction
articles.snippet: The accusation that former President Donald J. Trump wanted security camera footage deleted at Mar-a-Lago added to a pattern of concerns about his attempts to stymie prosecutors.
articles.abstract: The accusation that former President Donald J. Trump wanted security camera footage deleted at Mar-a-Lago added to a pattern of concerns about his attempts to stymie prosecutors.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Robert S. Mueller III, the first special counsel to investigate Donald J. Trump, concluded his investigation into the ties between Mr. Trump’s 2016 campaign and Russia, his report raised questions about whether Mr. Trump had obstructed his inquiry.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: After $700 Million U.S. Bailout, Trucking Firm Is Shutting Down
articles.snippet: Yellow, which received a pandemic loan, is winding down operations ahead of an expected bankruptcy filing. The closure of the company would mean the loss of about 30,000 jobs.
articles.abstract: Yellow, which received a pandemic loan, is winding down operations ahead of an expected bankruptcy filing. The closure of the company would mean the loss of about 30,000 jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Yellow, the beleaguered trucking company that received a $700 million pandemic loan from the federal government, notified staff on Friday that it is shutting down and laying off employees at all of its locations.

articles.headline: Fighting for Anthony: The Struggle to Save Portland, Oregon
articles.snippet: The city has long grappled with street homelessness and a shortage of housing. Now fentanyl has turned a perennial problem into a deadly crisis and a challenge to the city’s progressive identity.
articles.abstract: The city has long grappled with street homelessness and a shortage of housing. Now fentanyl has turned a perennial problem into a deadly crisis and a challenge to the city’s progressive identity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Come to Portland, his sister said. It’s green and beautiful, people are friendly and there are plenty of jobs.

articles.headline: U.S. Hunts Chinese Malware That Could Disrupt American Military Operations
articles.snippet: American intelligence officials believe the malware could give China the power to disrupt or slow American deployments or resupply operations, including during a Chinese move against Taiwan.
articles.abstract: American intelligence officials believe the malware could give China the power to disrupt or slow American deployments or resupply operations, including during a Chinese move against Taiwan.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is hunting for malicious computer code it believes China has hidden deep inside the networks controlling power grids, communications systems and water supplies that feed military bases in the United States and around the world, according to American military, intelligence and national security officials.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: A Climate Warning from the Cradle of Civilization
articles.snippet: How extreme temperatures and dwindling water are pushing the Fertile Crescent toward the brink.
articles.abstract: How extreme temperatures and dwindling water are pushing the Fertile Crescent toward the brink.
articles.lead_paragraph: The word itself, Mesopotamia, means the land between rivers. It is where the wheel was invented, irrigation flourished and the earliest known system of writing emerged. The rivers here, some scholars say, fed the fabled Hanging Gardens of Babylon and converged at the place described in the Bible as the Garden of Eden.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin and Bryan Denton

articles.headline: ‘We Are a Romantic Country’: On the Set of a Steamy Hit in Italy
articles.snippet: Italy falls for “Mare Fuori,” a television melodrama about the inmates of a juvenile detention center who pass the time making out — when not scowling at or occasionally stabbing one another.
articles.abstract: Italy falls for “Mare Fuori,” a television melodrama about the inmates of a juvenile detention center who pass the time making out — when not scowling at or occasionally stabbing one another.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before dawn, the teenage girls convened outside the Naples Navy base where the wildly popular Italian television show “Mare Fuori” is filmed.

articles.headline: The Secret History of Gun Rights: How Lawmakers Armed the N.R.A.
articles.snippet: They served in Congress and on the N.R.A.’s board at the same time. Over decades, a small group of legislators led by a prominent Democrat pushed the gun lobby to help transform the law, the courts and views on the Second Amendment.
articles.abstract: They served in Congress and on the N.R.A.’s board at the same time. Over decades, a small group of legislators led by a prominent Democrat pushed the gun lobby to help transform the law, the courts and views on the Second Amendment.
articles.lead_paragraph: Long before the National Rifle Association tightened its grip on Congress, won over the Supreme Court and prescribed more guns as a solution to gun violence — before all that, Representative John D. Dingell Jr. had a plan.

articles.headline: Russia Takes Its Ukraine Information War Into Video Games
articles.snippet: Propaganda is appearing in Minecraft and other popular games and discussion groups as the Kremlin tries to win over new audiences.
articles.abstract: Propaganda is appearing in Minecraft and other popular games and discussion groups as the Kremlin tries to win over new audiences.
articles.lead_paragraph: Russian propaganda is spreading into the world’s video games.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Kellen Browning

articles.headline: Excavations Uncover Hints of Nero’s Theater in Rome, and Much More
articles.snippet: A dig at a palace set to become a hotel has unearthed traces of a theater that archaeologists hypothesize was built by Nero, the emperor with a disputed reputation for tyranny and debauchery.
articles.abstract: A dig at a palace set to become a hotel has unearthed traces of a theater that archaeologists hypothesize was built by Nero, the emperor with a disputed reputation for tyranny and debauchery.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a 15th-century palace that is steps from the Vatican and set to become a luxury hotel, archaeologists did what they always do in Rome, an ancient city thick with buried treasures.

articles.headline: Amid the Counterattack’s Deadly Slog, a Glimmer of Success for Ukraine
articles.snippet: Recapturing the village of Staromaiorske was such welcome news for the country that President Volodymyr Zelensky announced it himself. But formidable Russian defenses have stymied progress elsewhere.
articles.abstract: Recapturing the village of Staromaiorske was such welcome news for the country that President Volodymyr Zelensky announced it himself. But formidable Russian defenses have stymied progress elsewhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: For 10 days, Ukrainian marines fought street by street and house by house to recapture the southeastern village of Staromaiorske, navigating artillery fire, airstrikes and hundreds of Russian troops.

articles.headline: Why One Country Is Struggling to Break Away From Russian Gas
articles.snippet: Austria, unlike most European Union countries, is still buying nearly as much natural gas from Russia as it was before the war in Ukraine.
articles.abstract: Austria, unlike most European Union countries, is still buying nearly as much natural gas from Russia as it was before the war in Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the 17 months since Moscow ordered soldiers into Ukrainian territory, countries across Europe have moved with surprising speed to reduce their longstanding dependence on cheap Russian gas.

articles.headline: Trump Crushing DeSantis and G.O.P. Rivals, Times/Siena Poll Finds
articles.snippet: The twice-indicted former president leads across nearly every category and region, as primary voters wave off concerns about his escalating legal jeopardy.
articles.abstract: The twice-indicted former president leads across nearly every category and region, as primary voters wave off concerns about his escalating legal jeopardy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump is dominating his rivals for the Republican presidential nomination, leading his nearest challenger, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, by a landslide 37 percentage points nationally among the likely Republican primary electorate, according to the first New York Times/Siena College poll of the 2024 campaign.

articles.headline: Who Paid for a Mysterious Spy Tool? The F.B.I., an F.B.I. Inquiry Found.
articles.snippet: After a Times report, the bureau canceled its contract with a government contractor that used the tool on its behalf. But questions remain.
articles.abstract: After a Times report, the bureau canceled its contract with a government contractor that used the tool on its behalf. But questions remain.
articles.lead_paragraph: When The New York Times reported in April that a contractor had purchased and deployed a spying tool made by NSO, the contentious Israeli hacking firm, for use by the U.S. government, White House officials said they were unaware of the contract and put the F.B.I. in charge of figuring out who might have been using the technology.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Ronen Bergman and Adam Goldman
